page.title: 01GREENHOW AND STOCKDALE MOORS
page.content: High above Ingleby Greenhow, spectacular moorland stretches over the hills, forming the north westerly corner of the North York Moors National Park. The area is England's largest stretch of heather-covered moorland, and provides food and sanctury for sheep and grouse in glorious but inhospitable surroundings. A rough track, unsuitable for conventional vehicles, cuts across this section, on its way from Ingleby to Helmsley, running parallel with and then crossing the 93 mile Cleveland Way. Today it is only walkers, riders on the bridle paths, game keepers, park wardens and intrepid motorists who experience the beauty of this spot. To the north west the view stretches out to the industry of Middlesborough; to the west down to the Greenhow and Battersby Plantations
